awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A High-Resolution Digital Fingertip
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to develop a high-resolution digital fingertip: a soft, easy-to-use, and compact sensor that will provide human-like tactile sensing. Such a sensor can be used to automate assembly tasks in next-generation factories, enable smart objects to understand their tactile environment, and equip scientists with a finger-like sensor for studying human touch. Industries have been transformed by the digitization of our auditory and visual worlds. A high-resolution digital fingertip will provide the mechanism for digitizing the tactile world, leading to applications and technological developments that will affect many industries.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop a soft, compact, and high-resolution tactile sensor based on elastomeric imaging technology. To achieve the desired form factor while maintaining a large sensing area, this project will develop novel optical and illumination configurations more compact than designs using conventional optics. These developments will demonstrate micro-scale imaging by a compact device and allow for modularity to expand the sensing area. This effort will lead to new insight into illumination design for shading-based 3D measurement, as well as optimizations to allow for real-time tactile information. The system will be coupled with a software development kit that provides real-time tactile information, including contact locations, force, and shape. The software development kit will make the system accessible to researchers and engineers from other disciplines, essential for broad adoption.  The high-resolution digital fingertip, together with the software development kit, will enable new applications benefiting from tactile information.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This SBIR project developed a tactile sensor for robotic systems that is soft, compact, and high-resolution. These properties, inspired by human tactile sensing, allow robotic systems to incorporate rich tactile information into their motion control processes. The sensor is based on GelSight technology, a soft elastomeric imaging system that converts tactile interaction into images. This project explored novel imaging and illumination design to significantly reduce the form factor of the sensor. The final outcome of the project is a tactile sensor with a 25 mm x 25 mm sensing area and a device thickness below 20 mm.

The intellectual merits of the project are the development of a compact hardware platform capable of capturing multiple types of 3D information, the demonstration of an elastomeric sensor cartridge with integrated illumination, and the development of robotic control algorithms for pick-and-place and insertion tasks. These tasks demonstrate that dexterous manipulation using tactile feedback is possible, enabling the automation of complex tasks that are performed by human hands today. Robotic systems with tactile sensing will have broader impacts on society by replacing human labor in repetitive and dangerous tasks, reducing labor shortages in manufacturing and agricultural harvesting, and enabling robots to operate in complex environments such as the home. The availability of tactile sensing as a new sensing modality will also lead to applications that are difficult to envision today, similar to the applications and industries that emerged after the digitization of images and audio. Due to its unique capabilities and rich image-based data, the sensor developed under this project can become the standard platform for high-resolution tactile sensing.

 


Last Modified: 04/26/2023
Modified by: Micah K Johnson
